title: Landmark ruling could chill IR class actions
text:
"There is no compelling textual or contextual argument which would suggest that this protection should be somehow extended to non-party funders who are using these claims to their perceived commercial advantage."

An order for security of costs in TESA and BHP cases would also apply only to the funder and the funder would not be able to recover its costs from employers if it won.

Augusta Ventures told the court this disparity would negatively impact on “the appetite of [the funder] to continue to fund representative proceedings in the industrial relations jurisdiction”.

But Justice Lee ruled that "if it turns out the Funder has not adequately factored that risk into the price it has contracted to charge, this does not seem to me to be something which should be of particular concern to the Court".

His decision would be different if he was convinced funding would be withdrawn or there was going to be "a stultification of the claims" but he said he was not satisfied that would be the case on the evidence.

"No doubt this will be an integer factored by the market into the price of the provision of litigation funding services in matters of this type," he said.

One of the reasons necessitating a security of costs was that Augusta Ventures was based overseas in the UK without assets in Australia.

The judge is still to decide on the appropriate form of the costs order, such as a bank guarantee or by cash, but said it would reflect anticipated party costs of the respondents. BHP and TESA are seeking about $1 million each.

The class actions were filed in June last year and allege that the labour hire firms engaged workers as casuals rather than permanent employees at BHP's Mount Arthur coal mine to avoid paying award entitlements. BHP is named as an accessory.

The law firm has also launched similar class actions against labour hire firms Chandler McLeod's Ready Workforce, Workpac, Hays and Stellar Recruitment worth an estimated $150 million.
description: A recent wave of class actions against employers over alleged underpayments has been dealt a blow with a ruling exposing litigation funders to costs if they lose.
